Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation2: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Story: I woke up to the smell of my mom’s special holiday bread, the kind she only makes when the whole family is together. Today was the big family celebration, and everyone expected me to be there, laughing, helping set the table, and joining in the games. My little sister had already texted, “Don’t be late!” But as I was getting ready, I got a message from Mrs. Lee, my neighbor from down the hall. She wanted to talk in the lobby about the noise complaint that had been going around. I knew she expected me to be calm, polite, and neighborly—maybe even help smooth things over since I’d always been friendly with everyone on our floor. My parents were calling me to come downstairs, but I could hear Mrs. Lee’s footsteps in the hallway, waiting for me. I felt pulled in two directions, my stomach tight with worry. I didn’t want to let my family down, but I also didn’t want to seem rude or uncaring to my neighbors. I stood frozen by the door, heart pounding, unsure which way to turn.
